awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Distorting the adversary's view: a CPS approach to privacy and security
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a novel Cyber Physical System (CPS) centric approach to privacy and security for wireless networked CPS systems, by reconciling the low-delay and low-jitter requirements of CPS applications with the requirements imposed by security and privacy. Our starting observation is that, in CPS, an adversary's primary goal is not to learn all the raw data, but instead core attributes, such as the state or control actions that are derived from  data. Building on this observation, we propose to use a distortion measure for security that maximizes the difference between the eavesdropper's estimate and the true value of the function computing the attributes of interest, reducing the adversary's ability to disrupt normal operation of CPS. We posit that we can protect these core attributes with fewer resources than needed to protect all the raw data. Ensuring secure and private information exchange over networked CPS systems is essential to building a thriving ecosystem of applications that range from autonomous cars and drones, to the Internet-of-Things (IoT), to immersive environments such as augmented reality for health, education, and collaboration. Our educational plan engages not only graduate students and postdocs but also high school and undergraduate students. It also reaches out to engineers and the lay public, by providing open source implementations of our algorithms  making them available both to industry and hobbyists. 

The project considers both passive and active attacks. We will quantify novel privacy and security measures for CPS systems  that are based on distortion measurements in a metric space; we will develop fundamental bounds as well as low complexity and low overhead coding schemes; we will quantify the disruptive power of active adversaries and design pro-active and retro-active defense mechanisms; and we will illustrate our approach over a flagship application, drone localization.  Our approach will offer an alternative to  wireless network encryption methods, by designing for low-delay, low-jitter requirements of CPS.

por.por_cntn:
This project,  which started in September 2017 was motivated by the simple observation that the characteristics of giving privacy and security in Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) systems could be different from other scenarios, since one could give a distortion-based measure for it. The project was arranged in three thrusts, with Thrust 1 focused on privacy, Thrust 2 studying security against active attacks and Thrust 3 on experimentation involving both numerics as well as small-scale deployments. We believe that we had significant results in the project towards these goals.

One measure of academic impact of the project is the number of publications during the duration of the project; nearly 40 publications resulted from this project (that acknowledged support of this grant) in top tier conference and journals.  It also supported (in part) the PhD work of 7 graduate students, one postdoctoral researchers and several undergraduate (REU) students. The three graduated PhD students have gone on to careers in industrial research labs.  Another measure of impact is the recognition of the papers and PIs through this project. For example, one of papers supported (in part) by this project was recognized through  the prestigious 2021 ACM Conference on Computer and Communications Security (CCS) best paper award. It also resulted in faculty research awards on related topics for the PIs from Amazon and other leading research labs. The research in this project also fostered a collaboration with industrial research labs (Google) through joint publications. The work was also disseminated through several invited lectures in various industrial and academics settings by the PIs, and through organization of workshops and conferences.

This project developed several fundamental ideas towards privacy and security of CPS and learning systems, which were discovered and published during the course of this project. The details are in the publications and were also summarized in annual reports of the project. Among the several works (including nearly 20 journal and journal-equivalent conference papers) we would like to highlight the following: (i) Distortion based Lightweight Security for CPS: we proposed new algorithms that used distortion-based metrics to protect CPS communication and showed that it is possible to confuse adversaries with just a few bits of pre-shared keys. We demonstrated this for system dynamics over a time-series enabling privacy of state-evolution and control (ii) Privacy in distributed learning: We demonstrated new distributed private compression schemes for achieving optimal privacy-communication and learning performance trade-offs. We also showed how to give the best known privacy guarantees for interactive protocols through tight composition of privacy. This line of work was recognized through a ACM CCS best paper award.  (iii) Symmetries and Isomorphisms for Privacy in Control Over the Cloud: Limited computation of lightweight CPS/IoT devices necessitates offloading of computation for control; we developed methods enforcing data privacy using symmetry transformations, enabling private control despite offloaded computation to an untrusted cloud (iv) Successive Refinement of Privacy: we developed new methods of privacy when here are multiple levels of trust between the IoT devices and an aggregator (v) Securing state reconstruction under sensor and actuator attacks: we  developed a theory and optimal algorithms for the resilience of linear dynamical systems to both sensor and actuator attacks, by developing a notion of ?sparse strong observability? and developed efficient methods using SMT solvers. We also characterized the computational complexity of securely reconstructing the state of a linear system (vi) Sybil attack resilient traffic networks: we proposed a Sybil attack-resilient traffic estimation and routing algorithm using limited legacy sensors and traffic dynamics  (vii) Secure Lightweight Entity Authentication Hardware Primitive: we developed a novel secure lightweight authentication hardware primitive for lightweight cryptography suitable for IoT devices (viii) Byzantine resilient distributed optimization and learning: we developed novel secure distributed learning algorithms that are resilient to Byzantine attacks; these algorithms are suitable for high-dimensional estimation, and give near-optimal guarantees of performance (ix) Drone experimentation for secure localization: using Crazyflie drones we validated our state-reconstruction algorithms in the presence of a malicious beacons which report incorrect time-of-flight information; see YouTube video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6G7zXLyQ4P8.
